content: The federal government has supported educational statistics for over 150 years, with the creation of the National Institute of Education and the National Center for Education Statistics in the 1970s. The Institute of Education Sciences now oversees federal educational research and statistics efforts. The National Institute of Education was replaced by the Office of Educational Research and Improvement in 1985, which later became the Institute of Education Sciences in 2002 through the Education Sciences Reform Act. The Institute is an independent research institute within the Department of Education, overseen by a Director appointed by the President. The National Board of Educational Sciences advises the Director on institute policies and research priorities. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) in 2002, with a Director appointed by the President and advised by the National Board of Educational Sciences. ESRA also created three National Education Centers within IES, later adding a fourth center for Special Education Research. P.L. 108-446 reauthorized the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) and amended ESRA by adding the National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER). Additionally, P.L. 107-279 enacted the Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA) and the National Assessment of Educational Progress Authorization Act (NAEPAA). ESRA, comprised of six parts, establishes IES to provide national leadership in education research. The aim is to provide information on education progress and practices for various stakeholders. The Institute of Education Sciences (IES) within the Department of Education aims to expand knowledge of education from early childhood to postsecondary study. It provides information on education progress and practices to parents, educators, researchers, policymakers, and the public. The IES Director is appointed by the President and is responsible for research priorities and evaluations in education. The IES Director, appointed under ESRA, must have expertise in research, statistics, or evaluation in education. They propose research priorities, establish review procedures, advise the Secretary, and ensure activities are objective and free from bias. ESRA also authorizes the NBES to advise the Director on policies and approve research priorities and funding. The ESRA authorizes the NBES to advise the IES Director on policies, research priorities, and funding. The Board also assesses progress and makes recommendations for improvement. ESRA specifies requirements for the Board of IES, including composition, qualifications, compensation, and travel expenses. IES consists of four research centers: NCER, NCES, NCEE, and NCSER, each with specific duties outlined in ESRA. Commissioners for three centers are appointed by the Director for up to six years, while the NCES Commissioner is appointed by the President for a six-year term. The four research centers under IES, including NCER, are headed by Commissioners appointed for up to six years. NCER's mission is to sponsor research that improves student academic achievement, closes achievement gaps, and promotes postsecondary education access. NCER's duties include maintaining peer-review processes, proposing research plans, implementing valid research, ensuring relevance to education practice, and disseminating findings. ESRA Part D authorizes NCEE to support evaluation and technical assistance for federal education programs. The mission of NCEE is to provide technical assistance, conduct evaluations of federal education programs, support synthesis and dissemination of results, and encourage the use of valid education research. The Commissioner is authorized to award grants, contracts, and provide technical assistance. ESRA specifies requirements for evaluations conducted by NCEE, including establishing evaluation methodology and adhering to high standards of quality. The Commissioner of NCEE is authorized to award grants, contracts, and provide technical assistance for evaluations. ESRA mandates high standards for evaluation methodology and quality. NCEE evaluates Title I programs under ESEA and supplements other federal education program evaluations. Technical assistance is primarily through the REL program. The National Center for Education Evaluation (NCEE) conducts evaluations for federal education programs, including Title I programs under ESEA. NCEE provides technical assistance through the Regional Educational Laboratories (REL) program, where 10 RELs are contracted to serve children nationwide. RELs focus on applied research, development, dissemination, and technical assistance activities to support SEAs, LEAs, school boards, and state boards of education. Their mission includes training and assistance on ESEA administration, valid research on teaching methods, assessment tools, and curriculum frameworks. The Regional Educational Laboratories (RELs) provide training and technical assistance to education agencies on ESEA implementation, research on teaching methods, and dissemination of educational practices. They facilitate communication between experts and educators, survey regional needs, and conduct applied research to support education goals. The Regional Educational Laboratories (RELs) work with educational experts, school officials, teachers, parents, and librarians to develop plans to meet state education goals, survey regional needs, conduct applied research, and disseminate findings. The Commissioner of NCEE ensures independent evaluations of RELs and shares results with relevant committees. NCSER sponsors research to improve services for infants, toddlers, and children with disabilities, support IDEA implementation, and evaluate outcomes. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) conducts research to enhance understanding of the needs of children with disabilities, improve services under IDEA, and evaluate its implementation. NCSER's duties include identifying effective practices, services, and interventions for academic achievement, promoting participation in general education, aligning state standards for students with cognitive disabilities, and addressing issues of overidentification and underidentification of children with disabilities. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) aims to improve academic achievement for children with disabilities by identifying effective services and interventions, aligning state standards for students with cognitive disabilities, addressing overidentification and underidentification issues, and improving personnel preparation. NCSER is authorized to award grants for research activities and disseminate findings and results. The Commissioner of NCSER is authorized to award grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements for research activities in accordance with NCER standards. NCSER is responsible for synthesizing and disseminating special education research findings.
